item.title: Police condemn Mong Kok protesters
item.description: The police have condemned protesters who blocked roads in Mong Kok last night, leading to officers using pepper spray and batons to move them. Twelve people aged between 13 and 43 were arrested. The police say two officers were injured in the operation to clear Sai Yeung Choi Street South and Nathan Road.

item.title: Pope condemns IS for 'brutal persecution'
item.description: Pope Francis condemned the "brutal persecution" of minorities by Islamic State insurgents in his Christmas message. He also urged people not to be indifferent to the suffering of so many around the world. Tens of thousands of people turned out on St Peter's Square to hear the Argentine pope deliver his message. The Pope appealed for an end to conflicts in African countries, urged dialogue between Israelis and Palestinians, condemned the attack by Taliban militants that killed more than 130 students in Pakistan last week, and thanked those helping the victims of the Ebola epidemic.

item.title: Bush Senior spends second night in hospital
item.description: Former president George HW Bush greeted Christmas Day in a Texas hospital, where he remained for a second night after experiencing breathing problems. Bush, 90, was admitted on Tuesday to Houston Methodist Hospital and was spending another night there as a "precaution," his spokesman Jim McGrath said. The 41st US president and the oldest of the four living former US presidents, Bush, who is wheelchair-bound, has seemed frail in recent public appearances. He was previously treated at Houston Methodist in November 2012 for bronchitis, and ended up spending nearly two months as a patient there.

item.title: Hundreds flee after rebel attack in Assam
item.description: More than 2,000 people have fled their homes in the restive Indian state of Assam after separatist rebels killed dozens of villagers, some of them children. Residents sought shelter in makeshift camps set up by the state government following a series of coordinated attacks by armed rebels on Tuesday that left at least 69 people dead, 18 of them children. Another three people were killed on Wednesday when police shot at villagers who went to a police station to demand justice over the attacks. "More than 2,000 villagers have sought shelter in relief camps. People are of course scared and worried about violence flaring up again," a state welfare official said. The tea-growing state of Assam in northeast India has seen violent land disputes in the past between the indigenous Bodo people, Muslim settlers, and rival tribes in the area.

item.title: Citigroup to sell Japanese banking
item.description: Citigroup said on Thursday it was selling its century-old Japanese retail banking operations to major lender Sumitomo Mitsui as part of an effort to shrink its consumer business globally. Financial details were not released, but Japanese news reports estimated the deal to be worth about 40 billion yen (US$333 million). Under the agreement, Sumitomo unit SMBC Trust Bank would acquire Citibank Japan's operations including 32 retail branches, 740,000 customers, 1,600 employees, and deposits worth 2.5 trillion yen. The transaction is expected to be completed in late 2015.

item.title: Mainland shares continue their rally
item.description: Mainland shares rose on Thursday after the government announced new corporate support policies aimed at boosting the economy, dealers said. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index jumped 3.4 percent to 3,072. The Shenzhen Composite Index rose 1.4 percent to 1,424. On Wednesday the State Council announced preferential policies for Chinese manufacturers, including a promise to extend financial support, especially to large-scale equipment makers, to expand their exports.

item.title: Some part-time ATV employees to be paid
item.description: Some of part-time workers at the embattled ATV channel say they have been notified that they will be given their October wages soon. Some of them have already received their cheques. The Asia Television employees still haven't received their November wages. The two accountants from Deloitte China, appointed by the High Court to join the management board of the station, said they are still looking for a white knight to come to the rescue. They ruled out selling the station's assets to pay its employees. The English news division employees say they will stop working from January First if their wages are not paid by end of December.

item.title: Security firm asked to probe note mishap
item.description: The Bank of China has instructed G4S, the security company responsible for the loss of the new banknotes to investigate the cause of the incident, and to carry out immediate remedial measures. The notes were scattered along the Gloucester Road in Wan Chai when it was being transported in an armoured van. In its statement, the Bank said G4S has already apologised for what happened, and said it will compensate for the loss incurred in accordance to the contract.

item.title: Protest group aims to rekindle spirit with songs
item.description: Members of the pro-democracy cultural group Hong Kong Shield, including singers Denise Ho and Anthony Wong, sang Christmas carols and songs linked to the Occupy movement at several spots in the city, including the Causeway Bay, Mong Kok and Admiralty protest sites. The group said their aim was to recall the spirit of Occupy protests and to urge the government to implement true universal suffrage. They will also perform at the Chinese University later in the evening.

item.title: Police hunt for missing Wan Chai cash
item.description: Most of the banknotes that were grabbed by passers-by from a Wan Chai road on Wednesday still haven't been handed in. As of 4pm on Thursday, less than HK$5 million of the missing HK$15 million had been recovered. Officers from the Wan Chai district police office in plain clothes returned to Gloucester Road on Thursday to collect information from the scene. The day before, people including car passengers and pedestrians, were spotted joining a mad dash to grab the windfall after three boxes of cash spilled out of an armoured van, scattering notes on the road. The officers checked with nearby shopkeepers and questioned some pedestrians to collect possible information about those who carried away the notes. Police said on Thursday that 27 people had handed HK$500 notes to them. Among those was one person who returned about HK$2 million. Another two people handed back HK$1 million each. The police said they would continue to gather evidence and track the whereabouts of the lost banknotes.

item.title: Citigroup to sell Japanese banking
item.description: Citigroup said on Thursday it was selling its century-old Japanese retail banking operations to major lender Sumitomo Mitsui as part of an effort to shrink its consumer business globally. Financial details were not released, but Japanese news reports estimated the deal to be worth about 40 billion yen (US$333 million). Under the agreement, Sumitomo unit SMBC Trust Bank would acquire Citibank Japan's operations including 32 retail branches, 740,000 customers, 1,600 employees, and deposits worth 2.5 trillion yen. The transaction is expected to be completed in late 2015.

item.title: Mainland shares continue their rally
item.description: Mainland shares rose on Thursday after the government announced new corporate support policies aimed at boosting the economy, dealers said. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index jumped 3.4 percent to 3,072. The Shenzhen Composite Index rose 1.4 percent to 1,424. On Wednesday the State Council announced preferential policies for Chinese manufacturers, including a promise to extend financial support, especially to large-scale equipment makers, to expand their exports.

item.title: Tokyo stocks end their winning streak
item.description: Tokyo stocks closed 0.3 percent lower on Thursday, snapping a five day winning streak, as profit-taking and a stronger yen dragged the market down in thin holiday trade. The Nikkei 225 index at the Tokyo Stock Exchange ended down 45 points at 17,808, while the Topix index of all first-section issues slipped 0.3 percent to 1,421. Markets in Hong Kong, Australia, Singapore, New Zealand, Malaysia, South Korea, India, the Philippines and Indonesia are closed today.

item.title: Tokyo share market off to a slow start
item.description: Tokyo stocks opened 0.3 percent lower on Thursday as the yen's fall against the dollar took a breather. The Nikkei 225 index at the Tokyo Stock Exchange was down 49.39 points at 17,804.84 at the start. Trading is expected to be thin due to the Christmas holiday. Markets in Hong Kong, Australia, Singapore, New Zealand, Malaysia, South Korea, India, the Philippines and Indonesia are closed today.

item.title: MF Global to pay US$100m fine
item.description: The U.S. Commodity Futures Trading Commission said on Wednesday it had fined MF Global Holdings for wrongdoing during the collapse of the futures brokerage. A federal judge in Manhattan approved a settlement in which the company will pay a US$100 million fine and be jointly responsible for returning US$1.2 billion in client funds that another unit had been ordered to restitute last year. MF Global went under in 2011 at the height of the European debt crisis when markets became spooked by the company's US$6.3 billion bet on European government bonds. U.S. authorities have accused the company of using customer funds to cover liquidity shortfalls. The Commission said it would continue its lawsuit against the firm's former chief, Jon Corzine.

item.title: US stocks close higher
item.description: US stocks ended higher on upbeat jobless claims data. The Dow rose 6 points, less than 0.1 percent, to 18,030. The Standard & Poor's 500 index was flat at 2,081. The Nasdaq composite rose 8 points, or 0.2 percent, to 4,773. Trading ended early on Wednesday ahead of the Christmas holiday. Markets will reopen on Friday.

item.title: Takata president steps down
item.description: The Japanese company, Takata, whose defective airbags prompted the recall of millions of cars, says its president Stefan Stocker is stepping down. Airbag faults have been linked to the deaths of at least five people. Shigehisa Takada, the companyâ€™s chairman and chief executive officer, will take over Mr. Stockerâ€™s roles.

item.title: China unveils new support for offshore investment
item.description: China will simplify currency rules and step up credit support for firms investing overseas. It was the latest move by the government to tackle excess factory capacity at home and help local firms grow globally. The government will cut red-tape for firms investing abroad, allowing them to exchange money directly at banks, no longer needing to register with the authorities prior to such deals. It will also widen the financing channel to help firms "go out" with more bank support for major equipment makers. The government has been encouraging outbound direct investment by local firms to help slow down the rapid build-up of the country's foreign exchange reserves and help improve local firms' competitiveness in the global market.

item.title: US jobless claims fall to almost two-month low
item.description: The number of Americans filing new claims for unemployment benefits unexpectedly fell last week, underscoring the economy's sustained strength. Initial claims for state unemployment benefits dropped 9,000 to a seasonally adjusted 280,000 for the week ended December 20. It was the lowest reading since November 1 and marked the fourth straight week of declines.

item.title: South Korea indicts Uber CEO
item.description: South Korea has indicted the chief executive officer and local subsidiary of Uber Technologies for violating a law governing public transport, becoming the latest jurisdiction to challenge the U.S. taxi service provider. The Seoul Central District Prosecutors' Office issued the indictment against CEO Travis Kalanick and the firm's Korean unit for violating a law prohibiting individuals or firms without appropriate licenses from providing or facilitating transportation services. The company says it respects the Korean legal system and will provide its full cooperation. Uber, through its apps, charges fees to play matchmaker for passengers and drivers - some registered as taxi drivers. This new business model has brought Uber to the attention of authorities worldwide.
